instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: (solved) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not charging
threads.message:
recieved this macbook with no green/orange light.
after i replace the battery can on but not charging still no green/orange light

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
17-18 3.6ohm
27-28 20ohms

after this i measured voltage pin 1 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> got 15v
so i thought is <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> i changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> came from working work still same.

got this voltage with working <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
1 - 15V
2- 2.5v
3 - 3.9v
9 - 0v
12 - 3.4v
13 - 3.3v
14 - 0v
15 - 0v
17 - 0V
19 - 2.4v
20 - 2.4v
25 - 2.2v
27 - 9.2v

threads.title: (solved) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> not charging
threads.message:
"2- 2.5v"
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not even powered up.

Check R/<DIODE>D7005</DIODE>.
